question: During one lunar month, how many complete rotations does the Moon make around its axis?

content.source_1: The Moon keeps nearly the same face toward Earth due to tidal locking; small optical librations let us see about 59% of its surface over time.
content.source_2: The synodic (lunar) month—new Moon to new Moon—lasts about 29.53 days.
content.source_3: The Moon’s sidereal orbital period around Earth is about 27.32 days.
content.source_4: In synchronous rotation, a body completes one axial rotation per sidereal orbit; for the Moon this means its rotation period equals its sidereal orbital period (~27.3 days).
content.source_5: During each synodic month, Earth advances roughly 30 degrees along its orbit around the Sun, making the synodic month longer than the Moon’s sidereal orbital period.
content.source_6: In everyday descriptions, people say the Moon takes about a month to go around Earth.
